rendering-methods.__comment-1: You can enable different rendering methods
rendering-methods.__comment-2: render is the default rendering method it creates a realistic image
rendering-methods.__comment-4: render-color-correspondnece-image renders the correspondence to the reference mesh as 3d positions as color coded value
rendering-methods.__comment-5: render-normals renders visualization of the vertex normals relative to the camera
rendering-methods.__comment-6: render-albedo renders the albedo of the face instance
rendering-methods.__comment-7: render-illumination renders a visualization of the illumination

morphable-model-parameters.__comment-1: A value of 0 for any dimension will return always the mean for this dimension

occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-1: The options for the occlusionMode are:
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-2: eyes - This mode retrieves the location of the eyes from the provided .tlms file and renders black circles over both eyes on the face.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-3: random-1 - A hand hides the picture on a random place in a random orientation.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-4: random-2 - A microphone hides the picture on a random place in a random orientation.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-5: box - A rectangle filled with an arbitrary color hides the image.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-6: box-skinColor - Boxes filled with the color at the tip of the chin hide the image.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-7: box-whiteNoise - Creates random rectangles on the face, filled with Gaussian white noise.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-8: box-<percentage> - Iteratively creates a box column-by-column that occludes the specified amount of pace pixels. It fills the rectangle with a random color.
occlusion.__comment-occlusionMode-10: texture - Fills a randomly placed box with a texture image.

__comment-landmark-tags-1: The tags specifying which landmarks will be stored in the tlms file.
__comment-landmark-tags-2: Each landmark tags needs to be stored in the model .h5 file.
